discussion.content: A. it defaults to script name, sourcetype also does the same

Selected Answer: A
the source and sourcetype fields default to the script's name. In this case, the sourcetype is explicitly set to lister, and the question asks for the source.

Thus, the value of the source field for events generated by this script input will remain as default, which is script name.

Selected Answer: A
script name

I think the answer is C since Data Integrity Check is done when data is being ingested which is the raw data.

comments.content:
I believe the answer is C. Splunk data integrity computes hashes on the raw data, and then a secondary hash on all of those hashes. C is the only answer that seems even remotely related, so that'd be my choice.

https://docs.splunk.com/Documentation/Splunk/8.0.0/Security/Dataintegritycontrol

discussion.content: Any ideas what is the answer here?

questions.question_text: Which of the following applies only to Splunk index data integrity check?
Which of the following types of data count against the license daily quota?

discussion.content:
Answer is D
"Windows internal log" is not a Splunk internal log.

comments.content: Agreed, even the provided reference in the answer clearly states "only data/log sent to Splunk affect license" and as such Windows, internal logs are external to Splunk and are sent to Splunk

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Sys Admin Pdf pg 46. Ans is D

splunkd (ie _internal _metrics, etc) do not count towards license.

The correct answer in this question is D.

Replicated/Summary does not count. People create a summary index to bypass licence usage at times.

Replicated data don't count towards license.
Summary data don't count towards license.
Internal logs don't count towards license.

so maybe D?
Sorry answer is B

comments.content: The answer is D, please read through the provided Splunk URL reference https://docs.splunk.com/Documentation/Splunk/8.0.3/Admin/Distdeploylicenses#Clustered_deployments_and_licensing_issues

Replicated data doesn't count against the license quota because it's essentially a copy of existing data that's used for redundancy and disaster recovery purposes. Since it's not new data being ingested or indexed, it doesn't consume additional license volume. This allows organizations to maintain data redundancy without impacting their license usage.

discussion.content: Answer is A
True, its C. Part of the indexing process is to measure the volume of data being ingested, and report that volume to the license master for license volume tracking.
Actually license metering happens AFTER parsing and BEFORE indexing, it's an intermediate phase.

comments.content: Nah, the indexing phase includes license meter and indexing. The license meter runs as data is initially written to disk

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C is correct

Data Admin - Slide 14
C. is the correct answer

comments.content: Can anyone help sharing the splunk admin pdf.

discussion.content: C. Indexing Phase

comments.content:
Agreed C. Quoting the reference URL, 

"When ingesting event data, the measured data volume is based on the new raw data that is placed into the indexing pipeline. Because the data is measured at the indexing pipeline, data that is filetered and dropped prior to indexing does not count against the license volume qota."

discussion.content: C. Indexing phase

questions.question_text: In which phase of the index time process does the license metering occur?

Which default Splunk role could be assigned to provide users with the following capabilities?


Create saved searches -

Edit shared objects and alerts -
Not allowed to create custom roles

discussion.content:
Answer is B
admin: This role has the most capabilities.
power: This role can edit all shared objects and alerts, tag events, and other similar tasks.
user: This role can create and edit its own saved searches, run searches, edit preferences, create and edit event types, and other similar tasks.

Selected Answer: B
B is correct
